00039 #region Derived From: Copyright 2005 Green
00040 // A fast random number generator for .NET
00041 // Colin Green, January 2005
00042 //
00043 // September 4th 2005
00044 // Added NextBytesUnsafe() - commented out by default.
00045 // Fixed bug in Reinitialise() - y,z and w variables were not being reset.
00046 //
00047 // Key points:
00048 // 1) Based on a simple and fast xor-shift pseudo random number generator (RNG) specified in: 
00049 // Marsaglia, George. (2003). Xorshift RNGs.
00050 // http://www.jstatsoft.org/v08/i14/xorshift.pdf
00051 //
00052 // This particular implementation of xorshift has a period of 2^128-1. See the above paper to see
00053 // how this can be easily extended if you need a longer period. At the time of writing I could find no 
00054 // information on the period of System.Random for comparison.
00055 //
00056 // 2) Faster than System.Random. Up to 15x faster, depending on which methods are called.
00057 //
00058 // 3) Direct replacement for System.Random. This class implements all of the methods that System.Random 
00059 // does plus some additional methods. The like named methods are functionally equivalent.
00060 //
00061 // 4) Allows fast re-initialisation with a seed, unlike System.Random which accepts a seed at construction
00062 // time which then executes a relatively expensive initialisation routine. This provides a vast speed improvement
00063 // if you need to reset the pseudo-random number sequence many times, e.g. if you want to re-generate the same
00064 // sequence many times. An alternative might be to cache random numbers in an array, but that approach is limited
00065 // by memory capacity and the fact that you may also want a large number of different sequences cached. Each sequence
00066 // can each be represented by a single seed value (int) when using FastRandom.
00067 //
00068 // Notes.
00069 // A further performance improvement can be obtained by declaring local variables as static, thus avoiding 
00070 // re-allocation of variables on each call. However care should be taken if multiple instances of
00071 // FastRandom are in use or if being used in a multi-threaded environment.
00072 #endregion
00073 
00074 using System;
00075 using MathNet.Numerics.Properties;

00077 namespace MathNet.Numerics.RandomSources
00078 {
00088     public class XorShiftRandomSource :
00089         RandomSource
00090     {
00095         const uint SeedY = 362436069;
00096 
00101         const uint SeedZ = 521288629;
00102 
00107         const uint SeedW = 88675123;
00108 
00113         const double IntToDoubleMultiplier = 1.0 / ((double)int.MaxValue + 1.0);
00114 
00119         const double UIntToDoubleMultiplier = 1.0 / ((double)uint.MaxValue + 1.0);
00120 
00124         uint _x;
00125 
00129         uint _y;
00130 
00134         uint _z;
00135 
00139         uint _w;
00140 
00144         uint _seed;
00145 
00149         uint _bitBuffer;
00150 
00154         int _bitCount;
00155 
00160         public
00161         XorShiftRandomSource()
00162             : this((uint)Math.Abs(Environment.TickCount))
00163         {
00164         }
00165 
00173         public
00174         XorShiftRandomSource(
00175             int seed
00176             )
00177             : this((uint)Math.Abs(seed))
00178         {
00179         }
00180 
00187         [CLSCompliant(false)]
00188         public
00189         XorShiftRandomSource(
00190             uint seed
00191             )
00192         {
00193             _seed = seed;
00194             ResetGenerator();
00195         }
00196 
00201         void
00202         ResetGenerator()
00203         {
00204             // "The seed set for xor128 is four 32-bit integers x,y,z,w not all 0, ..." (George Marsaglia)
00205             // To meet that requirement the y, z, w seeds are constant values greater 0.
00206             _x = _seed;
00207             _y = SeedY;
00208             _z = SeedZ;
00209             _w = SeedW;
00210 
00211             // Reset helper variables used for generation of random bools.
00212             _bitBuffer = 0;
00213             _bitCount = 0;
00214         }
00215 
00223         [CLSCompliant(false)]
00224         public
00225         uint
00226         NextUInt()
00227         {
00228             uint t = (_x ^ (_x << 11));
00229             _x = _y;
00230             _y = _z;
00231             _z = _w;
00232             return (_w = (_w ^ (_w >> 19)) ^ (t ^ (t >> 8)));
00233         }
00234 
00242         public
00243         int
00244         NextInclusiveMaxValue()
00245         {
00246             // Its faster to explicitly calculate the unsigned random number than simply call NextUInt().
00247             uint t = (_x ^ (_x << 11));
00248             _x = _y;
00249             _y = _z;
00250             _z = _w;
00251             uint w = (_w = (_w ^ (_w >> 19)) ^ (t ^ (t >> 8)));
00252 
00253             return (int)(w >> 1);
00254         }
00255 
00263         public override
00264         int
00265         Next()
00266         {
00267             // Its faster to explicitly calculate the unsigned random number than simply call NextUInt().
00268             uint t = (_x ^ (_x << 11));
00269             _x = _y;
00270             _y = _z;
00271             _z = _w;
00272             uint w = (_w = (_w ^ (_w >> 19)) ^ (t ^ (t >> 8)));
00273 
00274             int result = (int)(w >> 1);
00275 
00276             // Exclude Int32.MaxValue from the range of return values.
00277             if(result == Int32.MaxValue)
00278             {
00279                 return Next();
00280             }
00281             else
00282             {
00283                 return result;
00284             }
00285         }
00286 
00301         public override
00302         int
00303         Next(
00304             int maxValue
00305             )
00306         {
00307             if(maxValue < 0)
00308             {
00309                 string message = string.Format(
00310                     Resources.ArgumentOutOfRangeGreaterEqual,
00311                     "maxValue",
00312                     "0"
00313                     );
00314 
00315                 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException("maxValue", maxValue, message);
00316             }
00317 
00318             // Its faster to explicitly calculate the unsigned random number than simply call NextUInt().
00319             uint t = (_x ^ (_x << 11));
00320             _x = _y;
00321             _y = _z;
00322             _z = _w;
00323             uint w = (_w = (_w ^ (_w >> 19)) ^ (t ^ (t >> 8)));
00324 
00325             // The shift operation and extra int cast before the first multiplication give better performance.
00326             // See comment in NextDouble().
00327             return (int)((double)(int)(w >> 1) * IntToDoubleMultiplier * (double)maxValue);
00328         }
00329 
00349         public override
00350         int
00351         Next(
00352             int minValue,
00353             int maxValue
00354             )
00355         {
00356             if(minValue > maxValue)
00357             {
00358                 string message = string.Format(
00359                     Resources.ArgumentOutOfRangeGreaterEqual,
00360                    "maxValue",
00361                    "minValue"
00362                    );
00363 
00364                 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException("maxValue", maxValue, message);
00365             }
00366 
00367             // Its faster to explicitly calculate the unsigned random number than simply call NextUInt().
00368             uint t = (_x ^ (_x << 11));
00369             _x = _y;
00370             _y = _z;
00371             _z = _w;
00372             uint w = (_w = (_w ^ (_w >> 19)) ^ (t ^ (t >> 8)));
00373 
00374             int range = maxValue - minValue;
00375             if(range < 0)
00376             {
00377                 // The range is greater than Int32.MaxValue, so we have to use slower floating point arithmetic.
00378                 // Also all 32 random bits (uint) have to be used which again is slower (See comment in NextDouble()).
00379                 return minValue + (int)
00380                     ((double)w * UIntToDoubleMultiplier * ((double)maxValue - (double)minValue));
00381             }
00382             else
00383             {
00384                 // 31 random bits (int) will suffice which allows us to shift and cast to an int before the first multiplication and gain better performance.
00385                 // See comment in NextDouble().
00386                 return minValue + (int)((double)(int)(w >> 1) * IntToDoubleMultiplier * (double)range);
00387             }
00388         }
00389 
00397         public override
00398         double
00399         NextDouble()
00400         {
00401             // Its faster to explicitly calculate the unsigned random number than simply call NextUInt().
00402             uint t = (_x ^ (_x << 11));
00403             _x = _y;
00404             _y = _z;
00405             _z = _w;
00406             uint w = (_w = (_w ^ (_w >> 19)) ^ (t ^ (t >> 8)));
00407 
00408             // Here a ~2x speed improvement is gained by computing a value that can be cast to an int 
00409             //   before casting to a double to perform the multiplication.
00410             // Casting a double from an int is a lot faster than from an uint and the extra shift operation 
00411             //   and cast to an int are very fast (the allocated bits remain the same), so overall there's 
00412             //   a significant performance improvement.
00413             return (double)(int)(w >> 1) * IntToDoubleMultiplier;
00414         }
00415 
00430         public override
00431         double
00432         NextDouble(
00433             double maxValue
00434             )
00435         {
00436             if(maxValue < 0.0)
00437             {
00438                 string message = string.Format(
00439                     Resources.ArgumentOutOfRangeGreaterEqual,
00440                     "maxValue",
00441                     "0.0"
00442                     );
00443 
00444                 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException("maxValue", maxValue, message);
00445             }
00446 
00447             // Its faster to explicitly calculate the unsigned random number than simply call NextUInt().
00448             uint t = (_x ^ (_x << 11));
00449             _x = _y;
00450             _y = _z;
00451             _z = _w;
00452             uint w = (_w = (_w ^ (_w >> 19)) ^ (t ^ (t >> 8)));
00453 
00454             // The shift operation and extra int cast before the first multiplication give better performance.
00455             // See comment in NextDouble().
00456             return (double)(int)(w >> 1) * IntToDoubleMultiplier * maxValue;
00457         }
00458 
00486         public override
00487         double
00488         NextDouble(
00489             double minValue,
00490             double maxValue
00491             )
00492         {
00493             if(minValue > maxValue)
00494             {
00495                 string message = string.Format(
00496                     Resources.ArgumentOutOfRangeGreaterEqual,
00497                     "maxValue",
00498                     "minValue"
00499                     );
00500 
00501                 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException("maxValue", maxValue, message);
00502             }
00503 
00504             double range = maxValue - minValue;
00505 
00506             if(range == double.PositiveInfinity)
00507             {
00508                 string message = string.Format(
00509                     Resources.ArgumentRangeLessEqual,
00510                     "minValue",
00511                     "maxValue",
00512                     "Double.MaxValue"
00513                     );
00514 
00515                 throw new ArgumentException(message);
00516             }
00517 
00518             // Its faster to explicitly calculate the unsigned random number than simply call NextUInt().
00519             uint t = (_x ^ (_x << 11));
00520             _x = _y;
00521             _y = _z;
00522             _z = _w;
00523             uint w = (_w = (_w ^ (_w >> 19)) ^ (t ^ (t >> 8)));
00524 
00525             // The shift operation and extra int cast before the first multiplication give better performance.
00526             // See comment in NextDouble().
00527             return minValue + (double)(int)(w >> 1) * IntToDoubleMultiplier * range;
00528         }
00529 
00539         public override
00540         bool
00541         NextBoolean()
00542         {
00543             if(_bitCount == 0)
00544             {
00545                 // Generate 32 more bits (1 uint) and store it for future calls.
00546                 // Its faster to explicitly calculate the unsigned random number than simply call NextUInt().
00547                 uint t = (_x ^ (_x << 11));
00548                 _x = _y;
00549                 _y = _z;
00550                 _z = _w;
00551                 _bitBuffer = (_w = (_w ^ (_w >> 19)) ^ (t ^ (t >> 8)));
00552 
00553                 // Reset the bitCount and use rightmost bit of buffer to generate random bool.
00554                 _bitCount = 31;
00555                 return (_bitBuffer & 0x1) == 1;
00556             }
00557 
00558             // Decrease the bitCount and use rightmost bit of shifted buffer to generate random bool.
00559             _bitCount--;
00560             return ((_bitBuffer >>= 1) & 0x1) == 1;
00561         }
00562 
00574         public override
00575         void
00576         NextBytes(
00577             byte[] buffer
00578             )
00579         {
00580             if(buffer == null)
00581             {
00582                 string message = string.Format(
00583                     Resources.ArgumentNull,
00584                     "buffer"
00585                     );
00586 
00587                 throw new ArgumentNullException("buffer", message);
00588             }
00589 
00590             // Use local copies of x,y,z and w for better performance.
00591             uint x = _x;
00592             uint y = _y;
00593             uint z = _z;
00594             uint w = _w;
00595 
00596             // Fill the buffer with 4 bytes (1 uint) at a time.
00597             int i = 0;
00598             uint t;
00599             while(i < buffer.Length - 3)
00600             {
00601                 // Its faster to explicitly calculate the unsigned random number than simply call NextUInt().
00602                 t = (x ^ (x << 11));
00603                 x = y;
00604                 y = z;
00605                 z = w;
00606                 w = (w ^ (w >> 19)) ^ (t ^ (t >> 8));
00607 
00608                 buffer[i++] = (byte)w;
00609                 buffer[i++] = (byte)(w >> 8);
00610                 buffer[i++] = (byte)(w >> 16);
00611                 buffer[i++] = (byte)(w >> 24);
00612             }
00613 
00614             // Fill up any remaining bytes in the buffer.
00615             if(i < buffer.Length)
00616             {
00617                 // Its faster to explicitly calculate the unsigned random number than simply call NextUInt().
00618                 t = (x ^ (x << 11));
00619                 x = y;
00620                 y = z;
00621                 z = w;
00622                 w = (w ^ (w >> 19)) ^ (t ^ (t >> 8));
00623 
00624                 buffer[i++] = (byte)w;
00625                 if(i < buffer.Length)
00626                 {
00627                     buffer[i++] = (byte)(w >> 8);
00628                     if(i < buffer.Length)
00629                     {
00630                         buffer[i++] = (byte)(w >> 16);
00631                         if(i < buffer.Length)
00632                         {
00633                             buffer[i] = (byte)(w >> 24);
00634                         }
00635                     }
00636                 }
00637             }
00638 
00639             _x = x;
00640             _y = y;
00641             _z = z;
00642             _w = w;
00643         }
00644 
00648         public override
00649         void
00650         Reset()
00651         {
00652             ResetGenerator();
00653         }
00654 
00659         public override bool CanReset
00660         {
00661             get { return true; }
00662         }
00663     }
